sen.j: 斎藤 道三 / 斎藤 秀龍（さいとう どうさん / さいとう ひでたつ）は、戦国時代 (日本)の武将。
sen.e: Dosan or Hidetatsu SAITO was a military commander during the Sengoku period.
Dosan or Hidetatsu SAITO was a military commander during the Sengoku period.

sen.j: 美濃国（岐阜県南部）の戦国大名斎藤氏の初代当主。
sen.e: He was the first head of the SAITO clan, which was Sengoku daimyo (provincial lord) in Mino Province (present the southern part of Gifu Prefecture).
He was the first head of the SAITO clan, which was a Sengoku daimyo (provincial lord) in Mino Province (southern part of Gifu Prefecture).

sen.j: かつて、斎藤道三は北条早雲らと並ぶ下克上大名の典型であり、僧侶から油商人を経てついに戦国大名にまで成り上がった人物だとされてきた。
sen.e: Along with Soun HOJO, Dosan had been considered the epitome of becoming daimyo by gekokujo (the low oppress the high), who rose in the world from a monk, through an oil-seller, to a Sengoku daimyo.

Dosan rose in the world from a monk, through an oil-seller, to a Sengoku daimyo, and along with Soun HOJO, Dosan was considered the epitome of a man's rise to a daimyo by gekokujo (the low oppress the high).

Dosan rose in the world from a monk, through an oil-seller, to a Sengoku daimyo, and along with Soun HOJO, Dosan was considered the epitome of a man's rise to a daimyo by gekokujo (the low oppress the high).

sen.j: しかし、『岐阜県史』編纂の過程で発見された古文書「六角承禎条書写」によって、美濃の国盗りは道三一代のものではなく、その父の長井新左衛門尉との父子二代にわたるものとする理解が有力となっている。
sen.e: However, according to an old copy of 'Rokkaku jotei josho', which was discovered while "Gifuken-shi" (history of Gifu Prefecture) was being compiled, Dosan didn't complete dominating Mino Province in one generation, but his father Shinzaemonnojo NAGAI had also contributed to his gaining the province, which is now considered a reliable opinion.

However, according to an old copy of 'Rokkaku jotei josho', which was discovered while "Gifuken-shi" (history of Gifu Prefecture) was being compiled, Dosan didn't complete his domination of Mino Province in one generation, but over two generations with his father, Shinzaemonnojo NAGAI; this is now considered to be the reliable opinion.

sen.j: 父は長井新左衛門尉（豊後守）。
sen.e: His father was Shinzaemonnojo NAGAI (Bungo no Kami, the highest official in Bungo Province).
His father was Shinzaemonnojo NAGAI (Bungo no Kami, the highest official in Bungo Province).

sen.j: 道三の名として、法蓮房・松波庄五郎（庄九郎）・西村正利（勘九郎）・長井規秀（新九郎）・長井秀龍（新九郎）・斎藤利政（新九郎）・道三などが伝わるが、良質な史料に現れているのは、藤原（長井）規秀・斎藤利政・道三などのみである。
sen.e: Dosan seems to have used several names such as Horenbo, Shogoro (Shokuro) MATSUNAMI, Masatoshi (Kankuro) NISHIMURA, Norihide (Shinkuro) NAGAI, Hidetatsu (Shinkuro) NAGAI, Toshimasa (Shinkuro) SAITO and Dosan, but in the reliable historical materials only these names appeared: Norihide FUJIWARA (NAGAI), Toshimasa SAITO, or Dosan.

Dosan was known by various names such as: Horenbo, Shogoro (Shokuro) MATSUNAMI, Masatoshi (Kankuro) NISHIMURA, Norihide (Shinkuro) NAGAI, Hidetatsu (Shinkuro) NAGAI, Toshimasa (Shinkuro) SAITO and Dosan; however, Norihide FUJIWARA (NAGAI), Toshimasa SAITO and Dosan are the only ones that appear in reliable historical materials.

sen.j: 子に斎藤義龍、斎藤利尭（玄蕃助）、斎藤孫四郎（龍元、龍重）、斎藤喜平治（龍之、龍定）、斎藤利治（利治）。
sen.e: His sons were Yoshitatsu SAITO, Toshiaki (Genbanosuke) SAITO, Magoshiro (Tatsumoto, Tatsushige) SAITO, Kiheiji (Tatsuyuki, Tatsusada) SAITO and Toshiharu SAITO.

sen.j: 娘に姉小路頼綱正室、濃姫（織田信長正室）など。
sen.e: His daughters were a legitimate wife of Yoritsuna ANEGAKOJI, Nohime (legitimate wife of Nobunaga ODA) and so on.

sen.j: 道三は美濃の戦国領主として天文 (元号)23年（1554年）まで君臨した後、義龍へ家督を譲ったが、ほどなくして義龍と義絶し、弘治 (日本)2年（1556年）4月に長良川河畔で義龍軍に敗れ、討ち死にした。
sen.e: He ruled Mino Province as a lord until 1554, and then his son Yoshitatsu succeeded him. However, Dosan came in conflict with his son, and they fought at the Nagara River and Dosan was destroyed in April, 1556.

He ruled Mino Province as a lord until 1554, at which point he passed on his family estate to Yoshitatsu, but Dosan soon severed all ties with Yoshitatsu; Dosan was killed by Yoshitatsu's army at the Nagara-gawa River April, 1556.

He ruled Mino Province as a lord until 1554, at which point he passed on his family estate to Yoshitatsu, but Dosan soon severed all ties with Yoshitatsu; Dosan was killed by Yoshitatsu's army at the Nagara-gawa River April, 1556.

tit.j: 史料に見る道三の来歴
tit.e: Dosan's Career Appearing in the Historical Materials

sen.j: 「美濃の蝮」の異名を持ち、下克上によって戦国大名に成り上がったとされる斎藤道三の人物像は、1960年代に始まった『岐阜県史』編纂の過程で大きく転換した。
sen.e: Dosan had been described as a ruthless person, who was given the nickname of "Mino no Mamushi" (serpent of Mino Province) and became a daimyo by destroying his master, but such a image of Dosan was totally changed in the process of compiling "Gifuken-shi", which people started to do in 1960's.

Dosan had a nickname of "Mino no Mamushi" (viper of Mino Province), who became a Sengoku daimyo by destroying his master, but such an image of Dosan changed greatly in the process of compiling "Gifuken-shi" which started in 1960's.

Dosan had a nickname of "Mino no Mamushi" (viper of Mino Province), who became a Sengoku daimyo by destroying his master, but such an image of Dosan changed greatly in the process of compiling "Gifuken-shi" which started in 1960's.

sen.j: 編纂において「春日倬一郎氏所蔵文書」（後に「春日力氏所蔵文書」）の中から永禄3年（1560年）7月付けの「六角承禎書写」が発見された。
sen.e: While compiling the history book, they found "a copy of Rokkaku Jotei josho" dated July, 1560 among the "documents owned by Takuichiro KASUGA". (now owned by Chikara KASUGA)
sen.cmt: 春日力氏の読みが不明のため暫定で「ちから」とした。「六角承禎書写」は、「六角承禎条書写」と同じ。
sen.e: While compiling the history book, a document called "A Copy of Rokkaku Jotei Josho" dated July, 1560, was found among the "Documents Owned by Takuichiro KASUGA" (later renamed to "Documents Owned by Chikara KASUGA").

While compiling the history book, a document called "A Copy of Rokkaku Jotei Josho" dated July, 1560, was found among the "Documents Owned by Takuichiro KASUGA" (later renamed to "Documents Owned by Chikara KASUGA").

sen.j: この文書は近江守護六角義賢（承禎）が家臣である平井氏・蒲生氏らに宛てたもので、前欠であるが次の内容を持つ。
sen.e: This old document was written by Yoshitaka (Shotei) ROKKAKU, shugo (governor) of Omi Province, to the HIRAI and GAMO clans, and the letter is missing the former part but the rest of it says as follows:

sen.j: 斎藤治部（義龍）祖父の新左衛門尉は、京都妙覚寺の僧侶であった。
sen.e: The grandfather of SAITO jibu (Yoshitatsu) was Shinzaemonnojo, who had been a monk of the Myokaku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 新左衛門尉は西村と名乗り、美濃へ来て長井弥二郎に仕えた。
sen.e: Shinzaemonnojo took the family name of NISHIMURA, and came to Mino Province to serve Yajiro NAGAI.

sen.j: 新左衛門尉は次第に頭角を現し、長井の名字を称するようになった。
sen.e: Shinzaemonnojo's ability was appreciated by his master, and he came to be allowed to use the name of NAGAI.
Shinzaemonnojo gradually proved his talent, and he was allowed to use the family name of NAGAI.

sen.j: 義龍父の左近大夫（道三）の代になると、惣領を討ち殺し、諸職を奪い取って、斎藤の名字を名乗った。
sen.e: After Sakon no taifu (Dosan) succeeded his father Shinzaemonnojo, he killed Soryo (a head of warriors), taking various political positions, and then called himself SAITO.
sen.cmt: 左近大夫→sakon tayuという読みもあり
sen.e: After Yoshitatsu's father, Sakon no taifu (Dosan), succeeded his father Shinzaemonnojo, [Dosan] killed the heir [of the Nagai family], took over various political positions and then called himself SAITO.

After Yoshitatsu's father, Sakon no taifu (Dosan), succeeded his father Shinzaemonnojo, [Dosan] killed the heir [of the Nagai family], took over various political positions and then called himself SAITO.

sen.j: 道三と義龍は義絶し、義龍は父の首を取った。
sen.e: Dosan and his son Yoshitatsu came in conflict and Yoshitatsu killed his father.
Dosan and his son, Yoshitatsu, severed their ties as father and son, and Yoshitatsu killed his father.
Dosan and his son, Yoshitatsu, severed their ties as father and son, and Yoshitatsu killed his father.

sen.j: 同文書の発見により、従来、道三一代のものと見られていた「国盗り物語」は、新左衛門尉と道三の二代にわたるものである可能性が非常に高くなった。
sen.e: Because of the discovery of the old document, the established success story of Dosan, who gained Mino Province in one generation, was revised and now there is a strong possibility that his father Shinzaemonnojo would have contributed to Dosan's seizing Mino.

It has been viewed traditionally that Dosan took over the [Mino] province in one generation; however, because of the discovery of this document, it became very likely that this take over occurred over two generations, with Shinzaemonnojo and Dosan.

It has been viewed traditionally that Dosan took over the [Mino] province in one generation; however, because of the discovery of this document, it became very likely that this take over occurred over two generations, with Shinzaemonnojo and Dosan.

sen.j: 父の新左衛門尉と見られる名が古文書からも検出されており、大永6年（1526年）6月付け「東大寺定使下向注文」（『筒井寛聖氏所蔵文書』所収）および大永8年2月19日付「幕府奉行人奉書案」（『秋田藩採集古文書』所収）に「長井新左衛門尉」の名が見えている。
sen.e: The name of 'Shinzaemonnojo NAGAI', which seems to be Dosan's father, appeared in these 2 old documents: "Todai-ji Temple Joshi Geko Chumon" dated July, 1526 (collected in the documents preserved by Kansei TSUTSUI) and "Bakufu Bugyonin Hoshoan" dated February 19th, 1528 (collected in "Old Documents Gathered by Akita Domain).

The name, "Shinzaemonnojo NAGAI", which is considered to be Dosan's father's, is also detected in old documents; his name appears in "Todai-ji Temple Joshi Geko Chumon" dated July, 1526 (collected in "The Documents Preserved by Kansei TSUTSUI") and "Bakufu Bugyonin Hoshoan" dated February 19th, 1528 (collected in "Old Documents Gathered by Akita Domain").

The name, "Shinzaemonnojo NAGAI," which is considered to be Dosan's father's, is also detected in old documents; his name appears in "Todai-ji Temple Joshi Geko Chumon" dated July, 1526 (collected in "The Documents Preserved by Kansei TSUTSUI") and "Bakufu Bugyonin Hoshoan" dated February 19th, 1528 (collected in "Old Documents Gathered by Akita Domain").

sen.j: 一方、道三の史料上の初出は天文2年（1533年）6月付け文書に見える「藤原規秀」であり、同年11月26日付の長井景弘・長井規秀連署状にもその名が見える。
sen.e: While Dosan's name 'Norihide FUJIWARA' first appeared in the document dated July, 1533, and the joint signature of Kagehiro NAGAI and Norihide NAGAI can be seen in the document dated November 26 of the same year.

On the other hand, the first time Dosan's name appears in historical materials is as "Norihide FUJIWARA" in a document dated June, 1533; this name also appears in a document signed jointly by Kagehiro NAGAI and Norihide NAGAI, dated November 26 of the same year.

On the other hand, the first time Dosan's name appears in historical materials is as "Norihide FUJIWARA" in a document dated June, 1533; this name also appears in a document signed jointly by Kagehiro NAGAI and Norihide NAGAI, dated November 26 of the same year.

sen.j: 以下、かつて知られていた道三像を中心に叙述していく。

sen.j: 明応3年（1494年）に山城国乙訓郡西岡で生まれたとされてきたが、生年については永正元年（1504年）とする説があり、生誕地についても諸説ある。
sen.e: It had been said that Dosan was born at Nishino oka, Otokuni District, Yamashiro Province in 1494, but some people claim that he was born in 1504, and there are various different presumptions of his birthplace.

sen.j: 『美濃国諸旧記』によると先祖代々北面の武士をつとめ、父は松波左近将監基宗といい、事情によって牢人となり西岡に住んでいたという。
sen.e: According to "Mino no Kuni Shokyuki", his ancestors had been working as Hokumen no bushi (royal guards), and his father had been called MATSUNAMI Sakon Shogen Motomune, living in Nishino oka as Ronin (samurai with no lord) for some reason.

According to "Mino no Kuni Shokyuki", his ancestors worked as Hokumen no bushi (royal guards) for generations; his father was called MATSUNAMI Sakon Shogen Motomune, living in Nishino oka as a Ronin (samurai with no lord) for [unrevealed] reasons.

According to "Mino no Kuni Shokyuki," his ancestors worked as Hokumen no bushi (royal guards) for generations; his father was called MATSUNAMI Sakon Shogen Motomune, living in Nishino oka as a Ronin (samurai with no lord) for [unrevealed] reasons.

sen.j: 道三は幼名を峰丸といい、11歳の春に京都妙覚寺で得度を受け、法蓮房の名で僧侶となった。
sen.e: Dosan's childhood name was Minemaru, and he entered the Buddhist priesthood at Myokaku-ji Temple in Kyoto in the spring of 11, being given the Buddhist name Horenbo.
Dosan's childhood name was Minemaru, and he entered Buddhist priesthood at Myokaku-ji Temple in Kyoto in the spring time when he was 11 years old, and he was given the Buddhist name Horenbo.

sen.j: その後、法弟であり学友の日護房（南陽房）が美濃国厚見郡今泉の常在寺 (岐阜市)へ住職として赴くと、法蓮房もそれを契機に還俗して庄五郎（庄九郎とも）と名乗った。
sen.e: Years later when his younger fellow monk Nichigobo (Namyobo) moved to Jozai-ji Temple (located in present Gifu City) in Imaizumi, Atsumi District, Mino Province, to be a chief priest, Horenbo left the Myokaku-ji Temple to return to a secular life and called himself Shogoro (or Kankuro).

Later, when his younger fellow monk Nichigobo (Namyobo) moved to Jozai-ji Temple (located in present-day Gifu City) in Imaizumi, Atsumi District, Mino Province, to become a chief priest, Horenbo left the Myokaku-ji Temple to return to a secular life and called himself Shogoro (or Kankuro).

sen.j: 油問屋の奈良屋又兵衛の娘をめとった庄五郎は、油商人となり山崎屋を称した。
sen.e: Shogoro (Dosan) got married with a daughter of an oil merchant Matabe NARAYA, and became an oil-seller designating himself Yamazaki-ya.
Shogoro (Dosan) married a daughter of an oil merchant Matabe NARAYA, and became an oil-seller using the name Yamazaki-ya.

sen.e: Shogoro (Dosan) married a daughter of an oil merchant Matabe NARAYA, and became an oil-seller using the name Yamazaki-ya.

sen.j: 庄五郎は油売り行商を重ねていたが、あるとき美濃常在寺の日護房改め日運と再会し、日運の縁故を頼った庄五郎は、美濃守護土岐氏小守護代の長井長弘家臣となることに成功した。
sen.e: Shogoro (Dosan), hawking oil on the road, one day came across Nichiun (once known as Nichigobo) of the Jozai-ji Temple in Mino, so asked Nichiun to make him a retainer of Nagahiro NAGAI, Koshugodai (junior deputy shugo) of the TOKI clan, which was Shugo (provincial governor) of Mino Province.

Shogoro (Dosan), hawking oil on the road, one day came across Nichiun (once known as Nichigobo) of the Jozai-ji Temple in Mino; counting on their old friendship he succeeded in becoming a retainer of Nagahiro NAGAI, Koshugodai (junior deputy shugo) of the TOKI clan, which was Shugo (provincial governor) of Mino Province.

sen.j: 庄五郎は、長井氏斎藤長井氏家臣西村氏の家名をついで西村勘九郎正利を称した。
sen.e: Shogoro (Dosan) came to designate himself NISHIMURA Kankuro Masatoshi, inheriting the family name of the NISHIMURA clan, which was retainers of the NAGAI SAITO NAGAI clan.

sen.j: 勘九郎はその武芸と才覚で次第に頭角をあらわし、土岐守護の次男である土岐頼芸の信頼を得るに至った。
sen.e: Kankuro (Dosan) gradually came to gain trust of Yorinari TOKI, the second son of shugo TOKI, displaying his ability in martial arts and shrewdness.
sen.cmt: 頼芸の読みは他に「よりのり」、「よりよし」、「よりあき」がある。大きな事典では「よりなり」表記が多い。
sen.e: Kankuro (Dosan) gradually proved his talent through martial arts and his quick wit, and he gained trust of Yorinari TOKI, the second son of shugo TOKI.
Kankuro (Dosan) gradually proved his talent through martial arts and his quick wit, and he gained trust of Yorinari TOKI, the second son of shugo TOKI.

sen.j: 頼芸が兄土岐政頼との家督相続に敗れると、勘九郎は密かに策を講じ、大永7年8月、政頼を革手城に急襲して越前へ追いやり、頼芸の守護補任に大きく貢献した。
sen.e: When Yorinari was defeated by his older brother Masayori TOKI in a succession struggle, Kankuro (Dosan) secretly plotted a sudden attack against Masayori at Kawate-jo Castle and contributed to set Yorinari in a position of shugo, driving Masayori out to Echizen.

When Yorinari lost to his older brother Masayori TOKI in a succession struggle, Kankuro (Dosan) secretly plotted a sudden attack against Masayori at Kawate-jo Castle and drove him out to Echizen, which greatly contributed to Yorinari's assignment to shugo.

sen.j: 頼芸の信任篤い勘九郎は、同じく頼芸の信任を得ていた長井長弘の除去を画策し、享禄3年（1530年）正月ないし天文2年（1533年）に長井長弘を不行跡のかどで殺害し、長井新九郎規秀を名乗った。
sen.e: Trusted greatly by Yorinari, Kankuro (Dosan) plotted to eliminate Nagahiro NAGAI, on whom Yorinari also placed reliance, and killed Nagahiro for a minor reason in 1530 (or 1533), and then Kankuro (Dosan) took the name of NAGAI Shinkuro Norihide.

sen.e: In 1538, when Toshinaga SAITO, shugodai (deputy shugo) of Mino Province, died of sickness, Shinkuro (Dosan) inherited Toshinaga's family name and called himself SAITO Shinkuro Toshimasa.

sen.j: 天文10年（1541年）、利政による土岐頼満（頼芸の弟）の毒殺が契機となって、頼芸と利政との対立抗争が開始した。
sen.e: In 1541, Toshimasa (Dosan) poisoned Yorimitsu TOKI (Yorinari's younger brother) to death, which caused a conflict between Yorinari and Toshimasa (Dosan).

sen.e: Though Toshimasa (Dosan) was in a difficult situation for a short time, he attacked Yorinari's residence Oga-jo Castle and expelled Yorinari and his son Jiro to Owari Province,becoming a virtual ruler of the Mino Province.

sen.e: However, Yorinari got a support of Nobuhide ODA and made an ally of Masayori, who had been banished and got a help of Kagetaka ASAKURA (the tenth master of the house). sen.e: In September, 1547, Nobuhide ODA made a grand attack against Toshimasa (Dosan) at Inabayama-jo Castle, but Toshimasa (Dosan) shut up the Castle completely and drove the ODA's army to the brink of destruction. (Battle of Kanoguchi).

sen.e: In such a situation, Toshimasa (Dosan) was reconciled with Nobuhide ODA, and made his daughter Kicho marry Nobuhide's eldest son Nobunaga ODA in 1548.

sen.j: 帰蝶を信長に嫁がせた後の聖徳寺（現在の愛知県一宮市（旧尾西市）冨田）で会見した際、「うつけ者」と評されていた信長が多数の鉄砲を護衛に装備させ正装で訪れたことに大変驚き、斎藤利政は信長を見込むと同時に、「我が子たちはあのうつけ（信長）の馬をつなぐようになる」と述べたと信長公記にある。
sen.e: According to "Shincho Koki" (biography of Nobunaga ODA),, Toshimasa (Dosan) saw Nobunaga at Shotoku-ji Temple (present Tomida, Ichinomiya City (former Nishio City), Aichi Prefecture) and got surprised because Nobunaga had been considered an idiot but he showed up in full dress, making his guards armed with many rifles. Toshimasa SAITO (Dosan) predicted a bright future for him and said, "My sons are to tie a horse to a gate for him."
sen.cmt: 脚注の混入を分離して復元。信長公記はNobunaga Kokiの読みもあり。
sen.e: According to "Shincho Koki" (biography of Nobunaga ODA), Toshimasa (Dosan) was very surprised when he met Nobunaga at Shotoku-ji Temple (present-day Tomida, Ichinomiya City (former Nishio City), Aichi Prefecture) after Kicho married Nobunaga, because even though Nobunaga was known as empty-headed he showed up formally dressed and he had his guards equipped with many rifles; Toshimasa SAITO (Dosan) anticipated a bright future for Nobunaga and said, "My sons will be tying that empty-headed man's (Nobunanga's) horse."

sen.j: この和睦により、織田家の後援を受けて利政に反逆していた相羽城主長屋景興や揖斐城主揖斐光親らを滅ぼし、さらに揖斐北方城にとどまっていた土岐頼芸を天文21年（1552年）に再び尾張へ追放し、美濃を完全に平定した。
sen.e: After the reconciliation with Nobuhide, Toshimasa (Dosan) defeated these rebels: Kageoki NAGAYA, who was an owner of the Aiba-jo Castle and against Toshimasa (Dosan) with the help of the ODA clan, and Mitsuchika IBI, an owner of the Ibi-jo Castle. Moreover, Toshimasa (Dosan) expelled Yorinari TOKI, who had remained in the Ibi Kitakata-jo Castle, to Owari Province again in 1552, dominating Mino Province completely.

Because of this reconciliation Toshimasa (Dosan) gained support of the ODA family and defeated the rebels who were against him, including the head of Aiba-jo Castle, Kageoki NAGAYA, and the head of Ibi-jo Castle, Mitsuchika IBI; furthermore, he expelled Yorinari TOKI, who had remained in the Ibi Kitakata-jo Castle, once again to Owari Province, and he completely restored order in Mino Province.

sen.j: 美濃平定後、稲葉山城の七曲百曲口に「主を斬り、婿を殺すは身の（美濃）おはり（尾張）。

sen.j: 天文23年（1554年）、利政は家督を子の斎藤義龍へ譲り、自らは常在寺で剃髪入道を遂げて道三と号し、鷺山城に隠居した。

sen.j: しかし道三は義龍よりも、その弟である龍重や龍定を偏愛し、ついに義龍の廃嫡を考え始めたとされる。
sen.e: However, Dosan cherished Yoshitatsu's younger brothers Tatsushige and Tatsusada more than Yoshitatsu, and finally seemed to begin thinking about removing Yoshitasu from the position as a head of the family.

sen.e: It is because Yoshitatsu was born in 1527, and her mother Miyoshino gave birth to him within a year since Yorinari TOKI gave her away to Dosan.

sen.j: 国盗りの経緯から道三に味方しようとする旧土岐家家臣団はほとんどおらず、翌弘治2年（1556年）4月、1万7千の兵を率いる義龍に対し、7千の兵の道三が長良川河畔で戦い（長良川の戦い）、娘婿の信長が援軍を派兵したものの間に合わずに衆寡敵せず、戦死した。
sen.e: There were virtually no retainers of the old TOKI clan who wanted to support Dosan because of his ruthless way of gaining Mino, and Yoshitasu gathered a 17,000-strong army in April 1556, while Dosan's army had only 7,000 warriors, and they fought at Nagara River (Battle of Nagara River), and Dosan's son-in-law Nobunaga sent his army to help Dosan but they did not reach the battle in time to offer any help. The odds were against those who fought in small numbers, and Dosan died in the battle.

There were virtually no retainers of the old TOKI clan who wanted to support Dosan because of the way he gained Mino; in April of 1556, Yoshitatsu's army of 17,000 warriors fought Dosan's army of only 7,000 men at Nagara-gawa River (Battle of Nagara-gawa River), and even though Dosan's son-in-law, Nobunaga, sent his army to help it did not reach the battle in time, and Dosan died in the lopsided battle.

There were virtually no retainers of the old TOKI clan who wanted to support Dosan because of the way he gained Mino; in April of 1556, Yoshitatsu's army of 17,000 warriors fought Dosan's army of only 7,000 men at Nagara-gawa River (Battle of Nagara-gawa River), and even though Dosan's son-in-law, Nobunaga, sent his army to help it did not reach the battle in time, and Dosan died in the lopsided battle.

sen.j: 享年63。
sen.e: The age at death: 63.
He was 63 years old.
He was 63 years old.

sen.j: 土岐頼芸は無能だったが、土岐家自体を慕う旧臣は多く、道三は美濃平定後も常に不穏分子に悩まされ、国内統制に苦慮している。
sen.e: Yorinari TOKI was said to be incompetent, but there were many former retainers who still wanted to follow the TOKI clan, and Dosan was always being annoyed with those disturbing retainers, having difficulty to rule over the province.
sen.cmt: 脚注の混入を分離して復元
sen.e: Even though Yorinari TOKI was said to be incompetent many former retainers were still loyal to the TOKI clan, and even after Dosan restored order in Mino he was always troubled by those who posed a threat, which led to a difficulty in ruling the province.

Even though Yorinari TOKI was said to be incompetent many former retainers were still loyal to the TOKI clan, and even after Dosan restored order in Mino he was always troubled by those who posed a threat, which led to a difficulty in ruling the province.

sen.j: そのため、微罪の者を牛裂き、釜茹での刑に処するなどの強権政治を行なっている。
sen.e: That is why Dosan abused authority, killing petty criminals by splitting their body using bulls or boiling them in a big iron pot.
sen.cmt: 脚注の混入を分離して復元
sen.e: This is why Dosan ruled by forcible measures such as killing petty criminals by splitting their bodies using bulls or boiling them in a big iron pot.
This is why Dosan ruled by forcible measures such as killing petty criminals by splitting their bodies using bulls or boiling them in a big iron pot.

sen.j: 勝俣鎮夫は道三から義竜への家督譲渡の背景には、実はこうした残酷な道三の姿勢に不満を抱いた重臣達によって義竜を擁した政変が引き起こされて、道三はそれによって当主の座を追われたにすぎないとする説を唱えている。
sen.e: Shizuo KATSUMATA expresses an opinion that Dosan's ruthless behavior aroused his leading retainers' complaints and they supported Yoshitatsu to drive Dosan out of his position.
sen.cmt: 脚注の混入を分離して復元
sen.e: Shizuo KATSUMATA expresses the following opinion regarding Yoshitatsu's succession to Dosan's family: Dosan's ruthless behavior caused dissatisfaction among his leading retainers, who, in turn, instigated a political change that supported Yoshitatsu, and as a result, Dosan was merely driven out of his position as the head of the clan.

Shizuo KATSUMATA expresses the following opinion regarding Yoshitatsu's succession to Dosan's family: Dosan's ruthless behavior caused dissatisfaction among his leading retainers, who, in turn, instigated a political change that supported Yoshitatsu, and as a result, Dosan was merely driven out of his position as the head of the clan.

sen.j: 戦死する直前、信長に対して美濃を譲り渡すという遺言書を残したと信長公記にある。
sen.e: According to "Shincho Koki", Dosan left a will just before his death that said he would give Mino Province to Nobunaga.
sen.cmt: 脚注の混入を分離して復元
sen.e: According to "Shincho Koki", just before his death in the battle, Dosan left a will that stated that he would give Mino Province to Nobunaga.
According to "Shincho Koki," just before his death in the battle, Dosan left a will that stated that he would give Mino Province to Nobunaga.

sen.j: 道三は義龍を「無能」と評したが、長良川の戦いにおける義龍の采配を見て、その評価を改め、後悔したという。
sen.e: Dosan had concluded that Yoshitatsu had been 'incompetent', but when he saw the way Yoshitasu was giving commands to his warriors at the battle of Nagara River, he changed his opinion and regretted what he had thought.
sen.cmt: 脚注の混入を分離して復元
sen.e: Dosan considered Yoshitatsu "incompetent", but when he saw the way Yoshitatsu gave commands at the Battle of Nagara-gawa River it is said that he changed his opinion and regretted [what he thought of Yoshitatsu].

Dosan considered Yoshitatsu "incompetent," but when he saw the way Yoshitatsu gave commands at the Battle of Nagara-gawa River it is said that he changed his opinion and regretted [what he thought of Yoshitatsu].

sen.j: 道三の首は、義龍側についた旧臣の手で道三塚に手厚く葬られた。
sen.e: Dosan's head was buried in Dosan Duka (grave of Dosan) by his former retainers who sided Yoshitatsu at the battle.
sen.cmt: 脚注の混入を分離して復元
sen.e: Dosan's head was courteously buried in Dosan Zuka (Dosan's grave) by his former retainers who sided with Yoshitatsu.
sen.cmt: Dosan Duka sounds a little strange so I changed it to Dosan Zuka. I don't know which is correct.
sen.e: Dosan's head was courteously buried in Dosan Zuka (Dosan's grave) by his former retainers who sided with Yoshitatsu.

sen.j: なお、首を討たれた際、鼻も削がれたという。
sen.e: It is said that Dosan's nose was also sliced off when he was killed.
sen.cmt: 脚注の混入を分離して復元
sen.e: It is said that Dosan's nose was also sliced off when he was killed.
It is said that Dosan's nose was also sliced off when he was killed.

sen.j: 道三の墓所は、岐阜県岐阜市の常在寺 (岐阜市)に営まれているほか、同市の道三塚も道三墓所と伝えられている。
sen.e: Dosan's grave is located in the Jozai-ji Temple, Gifu City, Gifu Prefecture, and Dosan Duka in the same city is also considered his grave.
Dosan's grave is located in Jozai-ji Temple, Gifu City, Gifu Prefecture, and Dosan Zuka in the same city is also considered his grave.
sen.cmt: First "the" in the sentence deleted; Duka changed to Zuka (but I don't know which is correct).
sen.e: Dosan's grave is located in Jozai-ji Temple, Gifu City, Gifu Prefecture, and Dosan Zuka in the same city is also considered his grave.

sen.j: 常在寺には道三の肖像や「斎藤山城」印などが所蔵されている。
sen.e: A portrait of Dosan and a seal of 'Saito Yamashiro' are preserved at Jozai-ji Temple.
A portrait of Dosan and a seal of 'Saito Yamashiro' are preserved at Jozai-ji Temple.
A portrait of Dosan and a seal of 'Saito Yamashiro' are preserved at Jozai-ji Temple.

sen.j: 後に江戸時代には、旗本井上家や松波家などが道三子孫として伝えられていた。
sen.e: Later, in the Edo period, Hatamoto (direct retainers of a lord) INOUE and MATSUNAMI clans were said to be Dosan's descendants.
Later, in the Edo period, Hatamoto (direct retainers of a lord) INOUE and MATSUNAMI clans were said to be Dosan's descendants.
Later, in the Edo period, Hatamoto (direct retainers of a lord) INOUE and MATSUNAMI clans were said to be Dosan's descendants.

sen.j: 現代に至ると、岐阜のまちづくりの基礎を成した道三の遺徳を偲び、昭和47年（1972年）から岐阜市にて毎年4月上旬に道三まつりが開催されている。
sen.e: Now Dosan Festival is held annually in April at Gif City to recall his great achievements of laying the foundation of the city.
Now, Dosan Festival has been held annually during the first half of April since 1972 in Gifu City to recall his great achievements for laying the foundation of the city.
sen.cmt: Sentence slightly modified; added some parts omitted.

sen.j: 親子二代説が登場するまでは「油屋から身を立て大名にまでのしあがった戦国大名」という道三像が定着していたことから、各種の民間説話・伝承や、二代説登場後のものも含む多くの創作作品においては、一代説を前提とした「斎藤道三」というキャラクターが語られることが圧倒的に多い。
sen.e: Dosan had been known as a person who 'had risen in the world from an oil-seller to Daimyo' until the old document was found which said that Dosan's father had also contributed to Dosan's gaining Mino Province. However the old image of Dosan was so vivid that in many of the folklores and creative works Dosan is still described as a person who rose in the world in one generation even after the truth was revealed.

Until the father-and-son two-generation view came about, Dosan's image was well established as a "Sengoku Daimyo who rose in the world from an oil-seller to a Daimyo"; because of this, in various folklores, oral literatures and creative works, including the ones produced after the two-generation view came about, Dosan was most often portrayed as "Dosan SAITO" in accordance with the single-generation view.

Until the father-and-son two-generation view came about, Dosan's image was well established as a "Sengoku Daimyo who rose in the world from an oil-seller to a Daimyo"; because of this, in various folklores, oral literatures and creative works, including the ones produced after the two-generation view came about, Dosan was most often portrayed as "Dosan SAITO" in accordance with the single-generation view.

sen.j: 江戸時代から道三は極悪人として語られてきたが、そうした従来の道三像を止揚し、時代の先駆者としての道三像を描いたのは坂口安吾『梟雄』（1953年）だった。
sen.e: Dosan had been told as a consummate villain since the Edo period, but it was Ango SAKAGUCHI who first stopped using the old image and described Dosan as an innovator in medieval times in his work "Kyouyu".

Dosan has been described as a consummate villain since the Edo Period, but it was Ango SAKAGUCHI who denied the traditional image of Dosan and described him as an pioneer of the era in his work "Kyouyu" (1953).
sen.cmt: Sentence partially rewritten; added (1953) left out in Trans 1.
sen.e: Dosan has been described as a consummate villain since the Edo Period, but it was Ango SAKAGUCHI who denied the traditional image of Dosan and described him as an pioneer of the era in his work "Kyouyu" (1953).

sen.j: 時代の先駆者としての創作イメージを決定的に定着させたのは司馬遼太郎『国盗り物語』（1971年）であり、同名のNHK大河ドラマ（1973年）だった。
sen.e: Moreover, it was "Kunitori Monogatari" (1971) written by Ryotaro SHIBA that completed the image of Dosan as an innovator, and so did the NHK Taiga TV drama of the same title (1973).
However, it was "Kunitori Monogatari" (1971) by Ryotaro SHIBA as well as the NHK Taiga Drama by the same title (1973) that established the image of Dosan as a pioneer of the era.
However, it was "Kunitori Monogatari" (1971) by Ryotaro SHIBA as well as the NHK Taiga Drama by the same title (1973) that established the image of Dosan as a pioneer of the era.

sen.j: 親子二代説にもとづくものも含め、その後も多くの創作作品がつくられたが、強い個性を持ち、時代の先駆者・変革者としてのイメージで描かれる傾向は続いている。
sen.e: Although a lot of creative works about Dosan were made after the truth revealed, there still is a tendency to describe Dosan as a man of strong personality and an innovator, including some works based on the reliable historical fact.

Since then, many creative works have been produced, including the ones that are based on the father-and-son two-generation view, but the trend continues in portraying [Dosan] as a man of strong character and as a pioneer and a reformer of the era.

Since then, many creative works have been produced, including the ones that are based on the father-and-son two-generation view, but the trend continues in portraying [Dosan] as a man of strong character and as a pioneer and a reformer of the era.
